text: i'm kenneth branagh and I'm the director
of Cinderella this is a scene about a
third of the way into the film where we
meet Cinderella
played by Lily James and the prince
played by Richard Madden and the scene
begins immediately after Cinderella has
surprised a stag which is being hunted
by a party led by the Prince but what's
valuable to the scene in our film is
that it's an example not always the case
in Cinderella stories of the heroine
meeting the prince ahead of her
appearance of the ball and for us it was
a key scene to establish a couple of
things firstly that if it's not love at
sight it's at least a very very strong
connection at first sight mr. what do
they call you you don't know who I am
and so a number of things went into the
preparation for it one was the
atmosphere itself we shoot the scene in
an area of the Windsor Great Park which
is essentially I suppose the Queen's
backyard turned back garden and the oak
trees around which our characters are
moving on these horses are over 600
years old so the atmosphere itself is
magical and it was pleasing to be able
to tell the actors that they were having
this magical first scene in a place
where these trees have been here longer
than Shakespeare and and then a quality
in the scene that was really important
was that the actors themselves rode
these horses themselves the scene and we
shot it many times began always with
these two real actors on these real
horses really galloping into the scene
so that the scene began with a certain
quite frankly sense of danger rather
than shoot wide shots at a distance and
then move in where often in a scene like
that the close-up might either include a
close-up of the actor that excluded the
horse's head and sometimes you put an
actor on a rig or sit them on top of a
ladder
in order to be more secure in order to
have focus more more settled we were
always had them all
was on real horses and we used long
lenses we were much further away but
using 100 mil lens 150 mil lens trickier
technically because it's hard for the
focus pull those two things happen it's
harder for them the depth of field is
narrow and and they're moving all the
time so literally keeping those eyes
sharp is very difficult for the focus
bullet need to be very very sensitive
and the other thing it does is it
crunches up the background so when
you're sharp on them obviously the
background is out of focus now that gave
me a quality that I wanted which was if
you like a sort of psychedelic primal
backdrop of natural colours so that this
feeling of this very male very female on
on horses that also matched in terms of
gender were facing each other in in a
very sort of primal natural setting and
in a way the long lens did two things it
meant that the horses were never spooked
by camera equipment too close to them
and the actors themselves because they
had to control the horses and because
the cameras were much further away were
far less aware of the artifice of it
oh oh
